questions.text: A female with abdominal pain and bleeding per vagina with 3 months of amenorrhea. On examination her BP was 90/60mmHg. Which of the following statements is/are true about ectopic pregnancy? Abdominal pain is the most common presenting symptom of ectopic pregnancy and may be present in at least 90% of the patients. PID and sexually transmitted infections are a major risk factor. Low values of progesterone are usually diagnostic of ectopic pregnancy, however there's no specific value to completely rule out or exclude ectopic pregnancy. Oral methotrexate is a viable medical alternative to surgery in ectopic pregnancy patients presenting with shock or renal failure. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abdominal pain is the most common presenting symptom of ectopic pregnancy and may be present in at least 90% of the patients. True. Abdominal pain is indeed a hallmark symptom of ectopic pregnancy, occurring in the majority of cases. It often presents with or without vaginal bleeding and can be severe in ruptured ectopic pregnancies. PID and sexually transmitted infections are a major risk factor. True. Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) and sexually transmitted infections, such as chlamydia and gonorrhea, are well-known risk factors because they can cause tubal damage and increase the likelihood of implantation outside the uterus. Low values of progesterone are usually diagnostic of ectopic pregnancy; however, there's no specific value to completely rule out or exclude ectopic pregnancy. True. Progesterone levels can help in the evaluation, as low levels may indicate a nonviable pregnancy, but they are not definitive for diagnosing ectopic pregnancy. Additional methods, such as ultrasound and serial beta-hCG measurements, are necessary for confirmation. Oral methotrexate is a viable medical alternative to surgery in ectopic pregnancy patients presenting with shock or renal failure. False. Methotrexate is contraindicated in patients with shock or unstable conditions, as it is only suitable for hemodynamically stable patients with unruptured ectopic pregnancies and normal renal and hepatic function. Surgical intervention is the standard treatment for patients presenting with shock.

Highyeild:

Management of Ectopic Pregnancy (As per NICE guidelines 2019) Expectant Management Medical Management Surgical Management Not doing anything Resolve by itself Follow-up Clinical stable & pain free Size of GS <3.5 cm with no FHR Sr. B-hCG <1000 IU/L Able to come for follow-up Methotrexate No significant pain Unruptured ectopic GS <3.5 cm with no FHR β-hCG <1500 IU/L Able to return for follow-up Significant Pain GS>3.5 mm with FHR β-hCG > 5000 IU/L Methotrexate 50 mg/m² (single dose is preferred) Check for β-hCG-Day 2, 4 &7 Salpingectomy (complete removal) Salpingotomy (incision → remove → suture) Salpingostomy (Incise →remove→ kept open) Drop in 15% of β-hCG from previous value → she is responding Less than 15% drop → Repeat Max. 3 doses→ Surgery Most preferred: Salping ectomy If only 1 tube-> gotomy or ostomy (recurrence is high) If β -hCG 1500-5000 IU/L → Either medical or surgical management can be offered Drugs used in Medical Management (Most PG Males are very knowledgeable) ● Methotrexate ● PGF2- α ● Mifepristone ● Actinomycin ● Vasopressin ● KCL

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Peripheral resistance to insulin leading to hyperinsulinemia

options.label: D
options.text: Increased plasma volume and RBC mass

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks Increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks Incorrect (not a physiological change). Blood pressure typically decreases in the first and second trimesters due to reduced systemic vascular resistance caused by hormonal changes (mainly progesterone). It begins to rise gradually in the third trimester, approaching pre-pregnancy levels near term. Hence, an increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks is not a normal physiological change . Peripheral resistance to insulin leading to hyperinsulinemia Correct (physiological change). During pregnancy, insulin resistance increases, particularly in the second and third trimesters, due to placental hormones such as human placental lactogen (hPL), progesterone, and cortisol. This can lead to compensatory hyperinsulinemia to maintain glucose homeostasis. Fasting hypoglycemia and postprandial hyperglycemia Correct (physiological change). Fasting hypoglycemia occurs due to increased glucose utilization by the fetus and placenta. Postprandial hyperglycemia occurs due to insulin resistance and slower glucose uptake by maternal tissues. Increased plasma volume and RBC mass Correct (physiological change). Plasma volume increases significantly (by 40-50%) to support placental circulation, and RBC mass increases (by 20-30%) to enhance oxygen delivery. However, the increase in plasma volume exceeds that of RBC mass, leading to physiological anemia of pregnancy.

Table:

#MANTRA Cardiovascular System Parameters which increase in pregnancy Parameters which decrease in pregnancy ● Cardiac output = Stroke volume x HR (↑ by 20%) All these increase in pregnancy ● Remember : Cardiac output increase by 40% during pregnancy, 50% during each uterine contraction in labour and 80% immediately postpartum ● Peripheral vascular resistances (as progesterone has a smooth muscle relaxant effect) ● Diastolic BP and systolic BP (Decrease in diastolic BP > systolic BP) ● Mean arterial BP ● [ Systolic BP + (Distolic BP × 2)] 3 Maximum risk of cardiac failure in pregnancy → is in Arterio venous O 2 gradient (venous blood causes more O 2 immediate postpartum period > intrapartum period >28-32 weeks of pregnancy.

questions.text: Instrument assisted delivery is not indicated in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cephalo pelvic disproportion Instrument-assisted delivery, which includes vacuum extraction and forceps delivery, is indicated in specific situations to expedite vaginal delivery when certain conditions are met. However, it is contraindicated in cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) because the disproportion implies that the fetal head cannot pass through the maternal pelvis, making vaginal delivery unsafe. Fetal distress Indicated. Instrumental delivery may be used to expedite delivery in cases of acute fetal distress (e.g., abnormal fetal heart rate patterns) during the second stage of labor when immediate delivery is necessary. Maternal exhaustion Indicated. Maternal exhaustion can hinder effective pushing, and instrumental delivery can assist in safely completing the delivery. Prolonged second stage of labor Indicated. Instrumental delivery is commonly performed when the second stage of labor is prolonged, provided there are no contraindications, such as CPD. Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) Contraindicated. In CPD, the fetus cannot safely pass through the maternal pelvis, making vaginal delivery via instruments inappropriate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery in this situation.

Table:

#MANTRA Forceps: Pros Cons ● More likely to achieve vaginal birth (9% failure rate) ● Increased risk of anal sphincter injury and altered fecal continence Risk of 3rd or 4th degree lac is 17-20% ● Less likely to cause neonatal cephalohematoma (5.2%) ● Not as "user friendly," and correct forceps cannot always be gotten emergently Vacuum Pros Cons ● Decreased risk of 3rd or 4th degree laceration compared to forceps (10-11%) ● Increased risk of neonatal cephalohematoma (9.4%) ● Easier to use, available emergently ● Less likely to achieve vaginal birth (failure rate 14%)

questions.text: A 14 year old came with complaints of acute urinary retention. She has not attended menarche and has cyclic abdominal pain. On genital examination bluish bulge is seen. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Imperforate hymen Instrument-assisted delivery, which includes vacuum extraction and forceps delivery, is indicated in specific situations to expedite vaginal delivery when certain conditions are met. However, it is contraindicated in cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) because the disproportion implies that the fetal head cannot pass through the maternal pelvis, making vaginal delivery unsafe. Fetal distress Indicated. Instrumental delivery may be used to expedite delivery in cases of acute fetal distress (e.g., abnormal fetal heart rate patterns) during the second stage of labor when immediate delivery is necessary. Maternal exhaustion Indicated. Maternal exhaustion can hinder effective pushing, and instrumental delivery can assist in safely completing the delivery. Prolonged second stage of labor Indicated. Instrumental delivery is commonly performed when the second stage of labor is prolonged, provided there are no contraindications, such as CPD. Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) Contraindicated. In CPD, the fetus cannot safely pass through the maternal pelvis, making vaginal delivery via instruments inappropriate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery in this situation.

Highyeild:

Imperforate hymen : is the urogenital origin. Failure of canalization may lead to formation of mucoceles, which may be recognized in early infancy and get treated. However, the anomaly often continues unrecognized until puberty, when amenorrhoea in the presence of secondary sexual characters, cyclic abdominal discomfort, urinary symptoms (retention of urine) O/E the palpation of a midline hypogastric lump . Parting of the labia reveals the presence of a telltale bluish bulging membrane in the region of the hymen that points to the diagnosis of hematocolpos. Rx: A simple cruciate incision followed by excision of the tags of hymen allows drainage of the retained menstrual blood.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. vaginal atresia is a condition in which the lower portion of the vagina is represented merely by fibrous tissue while the contiguous superior structures (uterus) are well differentiated. Option: C and D. statements are false:

questions.text: Which of the following is the smallest pelvic diameter at the brim?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Obstetric conjugate The pelvic inlet (brim) has several important diameters, and their relative measurements are as follows: Obstetric conjugate Smallest diameter at the brim. The obstetric conjugate is the shortest anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic inlet. It is the distance from the sacral promontory to the closest point on the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis. It is approximately 10.5 cm and represents the critical dimension through which the fetal head must pass. Diagonal conjugate This is the distance from the sacral promontory to the inferior margin of the pubic symphysis. It can be measured clinically and is approximately 12.5–13 cm . The obstetric conjugate is derived from the diagonal conjugate by subtracting 1.5–2 cm. True conjugate (Anatomical conjugate) This is the distance from the sacral promontory to the upper margin of the pubic symphysis. It is slightly longer than the obstetric conjugate, measuring about 11 cm . Anatomical conjugate This is another term for the true conjugate and refers to the same measurement.

Table:

#MANTRA Table: Boundaries of Pelvis Inlet Cavity Outlet Definition Brim of pelvis Above – inlet Below PLPD (SP, IS, T5 Tip) Obst. Outlet Anatomical Outl. a. Above PLPD a. Bony outlet b. Below AO (SP, Rami, IT, STL & Tip of coccyx) Shape Round Circular Diamond Importance Type of pelvis, engagement Diameter: a. AP – TC - 11 OC - 10 DC – 12, clinically measured b. Oblique c. Transverse 11 12 13 12 12 12 13 - 11 (Inter tuberous diameter) Clinically measured Sacro cotyloid (9.5 cm) BPD negotiate brim of flat pelvis Plane Imaginary flat surface with boundaries of inlet Plane of greatest pelvic dimensions PLPD (Plane of least pelvic dimensions) Axis D+B D D+F Important Points 1. Angle of inclination a. Erect - Pelvis tilted forward b. Angle 55° with horizontal c. X-ray – measured 135° / Angle between plane of inlet & L5 2. High inclination - Sacralization of L5: BAD because i. delay engagement ii. Difficult descent iii. Favor OP 3. Low inclination – Lumbarization of S1: No Importance Plane of least pelvic dimensions: Boundary of PLPD a. SP (Lower border) b. TIP of Ischial spines c. TIP of S5 Importance: FINAL F - Forward curve I – Internal rotation Na – Narrowest plane L – Levator Ani Origin Z- zero station of ahead E- level of external os D- Deep transverse arrest L - Origin of levator ani muscle LP - Landmark pudendal block In anatomical outlet – 1. Posterior sagittal diameter (8.5 cm or 3 1 / 2 "): AP distance between sacrococcygeal joint & mid point of transverse diameter of outlet (TDO). Clinically measured by the distance between SCJ & anterior margin of the anus. Imp. Prognosis for vaginal delivery 2. Subpubic angle: 85 o . 3. Pubic arch: Arch by descending rami of both sides, obstetric importance. Normally 6 cm in between the pubic rami at a level of 2 cm below the apex of the subpubic arch. Clinically , it is assessed by placing 3 fingers side by side. 4. Waste space of Morris

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, G2P1L1, comes for a quadruple test at 16 weeks. Which of the following is not included in the quadruple test?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dimeric inhibin B The quadruple test is a prenatal screening test performed in the second trimester (typically between 15 and 20 weeks of gestation). It measures the levels of four specific substances in the mother's blood to assess the risk of certain fetal conditions, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) , trisomy 18 , and neural tube defects .

Highyeild:

The four markers included in the quadruple test are: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP): A protein produced by the fetal liver. Abnormal levels can indicate neural tube defects or chromosomal abnormalities. Unconjugated estriol (uE3): An estrogen produced by both the fetus and placenta. Low levels may indicate Down syndrome or trisomy 18. Beta-hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin): A hormone produced by the placenta. Abnormal levels can indicate chromosomal abnormalities. Inhibin A (Dimeric inhibin A): A hormone produced by the placenta and ovaries. Increased levels are associated with Down syndrome. Why Dimeric inhibin B is not included: Dimeric inhibin B is not part of the quadruple test. It is involved in ovarian function and is measured in fertility assessments or ovarian reserve studies but not in prenatal screening.

Table:

#MANTRA For Down's Syndrome: 1st trimester 2nd trimester Screening test Nuchal translucency + BhCG + PAPPA, i.e. combined test Quad test/Triple test Diagnostic test (karyotyping) Chorionic Villi sampling Amniocentesis

questions.text: Early onset preeclampsia is defined before:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

34 weeks Early-onset preeclampsia is defined as preeclampsia that occurs before 34 weeks of gestation , while late-onset preeclampsia occurs at or after 34 weeks. This distinction is important because early-onset preeclampsia is often associated with more severe maternal and fetal complications, including fetal growth restriction, preterm birth, and placental insufficiency.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Before 28 weeks: Extremely rare and typically associated with severe maternal or fetal conditions. 30 and 32 weeks: These are earlier stages, but the accepted clinical threshold for defining early-onset preeclampsia is before 34 weeks . 34 weeks: The dividing line between early- and late-onset preeclampsia.

Table:

#MANTRA Classification of Hypertension in Pregnancy (National High Blood Pressure Education Program 2000 and ACOG-2013) Disorder Definition Disorder Definition Hypertension ● BP ≥140/90 mm Hg measured two times with at least 6-hour interval ● Chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia and eclampsia ● The common causes of chronic ● Hypertension: ○ Essential hypertension ○ Chronic renal disease (renovascular) ○ Coarctation of aorta ○ Endocrine disorders (diabetes mellitus, pheochromocytoma, thyrotoxicosis ○ Connective tissue diseases (Lupus erythematosus). ● The criteria for diagnosis of superimposed preeclampsia: ○ New onset of proteinuria >0.5 g/24 ○ hours specimen Aggravation of hypertension ○ Development of HELLP syndrome ○ Development of headache scotoma, epigastric pain Proteinuria ● Urinary excretion of 20.3 g protein/24 hours specimen or 0.1 g/L Gestational hypertension ● BP ≥140/90 mm Hg for the first time in pregnancy after 20 weeks, without proteinuria Preeclampsia ● Gestational hypertension with proteinuria Eclampsia ● Women with preeclampsia complicated with grand mal seizures and/or coma HELLP syndrome ● Hemolysis (H) ● Elevated liver enzymes (EL) ● Low platelet count (LP) Chronic hypertension ● Known hypertension before pregnancy or hypertension diagnosed first time before 20 weeks of pregnancy Superimposed preeclampsia or eclampsia ● Occurrence of new onset of proteinuria in women with chronic hypertension

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT part of AMTSL:

options.label: B
options.text: Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction

options.label: D
options.text: Administration of oxytocin after shoulder delivery

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bimanual compression Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) involves interventions to reduce the risk of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). The components of AMTSL are: Administration of a uterotonic (e.g., oxytocin): Given immediately after the delivery of the baby’s anterior shoulder or within 1 minute of delivery. Controlled cord traction (CCT): Helps deliver the placenta while preventing uterine inversion. Uterine massage after placenta delivery: Stimulates uterine contraction to prevent hemorrhage. Why Bimanual compression is NOT part of AMTSL: Bimanual compression is not a routine component of AMTSL. It is a life-saving emergency intervention used to control bleeding in cases of severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) when uterine atony is suspected and other measures fail.

Highyeild:

AMTSL components: Delayed cord clamping Use of oxytocin as 20 units in 1000 ml NS infusion Controlled cord traction

questions.text: When is delayed cord clamping done?

options.label: A
options.text: Term and preterm babies irrespective of birth weights

options.label: B
options.text: Vigorous term and preterm babies requiring resuscitation

options.label: C
options.text: Vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation

options.label: D
options.text: All term babies born at 37 weeks

questions.correct_answer: A. Term and preterm babies irrespective of birth weights
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Term and preterm babies irrespective of birth weights Delayed cord clamping (DCC) refers to the practice of delaying the clamping of the umbilical cord for at least 30–60 seconds after birth , and it is beneficial for both term and preterm infants.

Highyeild:

Recommendations for Delayed Cord Clamping: Term and Preterm Babies: DCC is recommended for all term and preterm babies, irrespective of birth weight , as long as they do not require immediate resuscitation. Benefits include increased neonatal blood volume, improved iron stores, and reduced risk of anemia. Babies Requiring Resuscitation: For babies who require immediate resuscitation, cord clamping may be done earlier to facilitate intervention. However, recent studies suggest that even for some preterm or vigorous babies requiring resuscitation, DCC can still be attempted if feasible. Vigorous Term Babies: DCC is safe and beneficial for vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation, but it is not limited to this group alone. Babies Born at 37 Weeks: While DCC is beneficial for term babies, it also applies to preterm infants regardless of gestational age.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option B. Vigorous term and preterm babies requiring resuscitation : Not all vigorous babies, whether term or preterm, require Delayed cord clamping. Option C. Vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation : While vigorous term babies generally do not require resuscitation, it is important to assess for any underlying conditions like meconium aspiration, which may still necessitate intervention despite initial vigor. Option D. All term babies born at 37 weeks : A baby born at 37 weeks is considered a term baby, but it still face challenges related to lung maturity, feeding, or temperature regulation, which require proper monitoring and care; it does not require delayed cord clamping.

questions.text: What is restitution in the context of clinical or physiological movement?

options.label: A
options.text: Passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck

options.label: B
options.text: Movement of the head by 1/8th of the circle due to torsion

options.label: C
options.text: Stretching of the vulval outlet by the head

options.label: D
options.text: External rotation after delivery of shoulder

questions.correct_answer: A. Passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck Restitution is a stage in the mechanism of labor that occurs after the delivery of the head. It is characterized by the passive movement of the fetal head to align with the shoulders as the neck untwists from the torsion that occurred during internal rotation. Passive movement of the head due to untwisting of the neck: Correct After the head is delivered, it rotates to its original position relative to the shoulders. This realignment is passive and occurs due to the release of torsion in the fetal neck. Movement of the head by 1/8th of the circle due to torsion: This describes the extent of the rotation during internal rotation of the head, not restitution itself. Stretching of the vulval outlet by the head: This describes the crowning phase, not restitution. External rotation after delivery of the shoulder: This occurs after restitution when the shoulders rotate to align with the pelvic outlet, causing the head to rotate externally. This is called external rotation or the second rotation , which follows restitution.

questions.text: A 35-year-old P2L2 woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge and normal cervix. The whiff test is positive. What is this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bacterial Vaginosis The patient's symptoms and findings are consistent with bacterial vaginosis (BV) , a common vaginal condition caused by an imbalance in the vaginal microbiota, particularly an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria like Gardnerella vaginalis . Key Features of BV: Malodorous vaginal discharge: BV typically presents with a thin, grayish-white, fishy-smelling discharge. Positive whiff test: The addition of 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) to vaginal secretions releases a characteristic fishy odor due to the presence of amines, confirming the diagnosis. Normal cervix: Unlike infections such as chlamydia or pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), BV does not typically cause cervical inflammation or tenderness. Absence of significant itching or inflammation: These features help distinguish BV from candidiasis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Candida: Typically causes thick, curd-like discharge with significant itching and vulvovaginal inflammation. Whiff test is negative. Option: B. Chlamydia: Often asymptomatic but may present with mucopurulent cervical discharge and cervical inflammation, which is not noted here. Option: D. Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID): Symptoms include lower abdominal pain, fever, and cervical motion tenderness, none of which are present in this case.

Table:

#MANTRA #Pelvic Infections: Bacterial Vaginosis Trichomonas Vaginitis Candidal Vaginitis Etiology ● Altered vaginal flora ● Increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis ● Trichomonas vaginalis ● Candida albicans Causative Organism ● Increased vaginal ph ● Sexually transmitted ● Decreased immunity Symptoms ● Fishy odor,no itching ● Itching and burning ● Itching, burning Ph ● >4.5 ● >4.5 ● <4.5 Speculum Examination ● No vaginal epithelium inflammation ● Strawberry cervix ● Inflamed epithelium Koh ● Positive whiff test ● The whiff test can be positive ● Pseudo hyphae seen Sexual Transmission ● No ● Yes ● No Treatment ● Metronidazole or clindamycin ● Treat partner also ● Metronidazole ● Oral or vaginal azole ● Partner treatment not needed

questions.text: A 26 year old P1L1 presents with abdominal pain. She has a past history of rheumatic heart disease for which she has undergone mitral valve replacement surgery and is on oral tablet Warfarin 3mg OD. On examination 14 weeks abdominal mass was felt. On USG, 8*6 cm unilocular cyst with reticular pattern was observed in left ovary. What is the next line of management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Repeat USG after 6-12 weeks The patient presents with an abdominal mass and a unilocular ovarian cyst on ultrasound, which is 8x6 cm in size. Given her history of rheumatic heart disease , mitral valve replacement, and Warfarin therapy , the management approach must consider both the ovarian mass and her anticoagulation status. The findings suggest a functional ovarian cyst , which is common in the early stages of pregnancy. These cysts are usually benign and can resolve spontaneously without intervention. Why the recommended management is Repeat USG after 6-12 weeks: Functional cysts : These cysts often form due to the hormonal changes of pregnancy and can spontaneously resolve. Repeat ultrasound after 6-12 weeks is appropriate to assess whether the cyst persists, shrinks, or resolves. CA-125 measurement : This is a tumor marker typically used in the evaluation of ovarian malignancy, but it is not routinely used for assessing ovarian cysts, especially in a young woman with no other concerning features. Surgical intervention : This is typically not needed for a simple, benign cyst, especially in early pregnancy, unless there are complications like torsion, rupture, or signs of malignancy, which are not present here. MRI pelvis : While MRI can be useful in characterizing ovarian masses, it is not typically the next step for a simple cyst with no signs of complications.

Highyeild:

Management of Ovarian Cyst: General principles:- Surgery for ovarian mass. Indications: Any ovarian mass which shows high-risk features on USG. Any ovarian mass >7 cm & adnexal mass > 10 cm irrespective of age. Raised CA125 levels in postmenopausal females (>65 IU/mL) Acute complication of ovarian cyst. For diagnostic purposes.

Table:

#MANTRA Physiological/Functional Cysts Type Description Presentation Ultrasound/Cytology Treatment Functional Tumors (all benign) Follicular cyst Follicle fails to rupture during ovulation • Usually asymptomatic • May rupture, bleed, tort, infarct causing pain ± signs of peritoneal irritation 4-8 cm mass, unilocular, lined with granulosa cells • If <6 cm, wait 6 weeks then re-examine as cyst usually regresses with next cycle • OCP (ovarian suppression) - will prevent development of new cysts • Treatment usually laparoscopic • Painful, multiloculated, or partially solid masses warrant surgical exploration Lutein cyst Corpus luteum fails to regress after 14 days, becoming cystic or hemorrhagic • More likely to cause pain than follicular cyst • May delay onset of next period • Larger and firmer than follicular cysts • Show a cob web like appearance Same as for follicular cysts Theca-lutein cyst Due to atretic follicles stimulated by abnormal B-hCG levels Associated with molar pregnancy, ovulation induction with clomiphene pregnancy • Conservative • Cyst will regress as B-hCG levels fall Luteoma of pregnancy • Usually bilateral • Due to prolonged elevation of B-hCG • Associated with multiple pregnancy • Same as for theca-lutein • Regresses postpartum

questions.text: An athlete with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2 presents with secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. Her laboratory investigations reveal FSH 2; LH 0.3; TSH 1.2. Prolactin 20ng/ml. What is the underlying cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism The patient's presentation of secondary amenorrhea , primary infertility , and a low BMI (17.5 kg/m²) is characteristic of a condition where the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis is disrupted, often seen in athletes with low body fat. This condition is commonly referred to as hypogonadotropic hypogonadism . The lab results further support this diagnosis: FSH = 2 mIU/mL (low or normal) LH = 0.3 mIU/mL (very low) TSH = 1.2 µIU/mL (normal, ruling out thyroid dysfunction) Prolactin = 20 ng/mL (normal, ruling out hyperprolactinemia) The low levels of both FSH and LH suggest that the hypothalamus is not producing adequate gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which in turn leads to insufficient release of FSH and LH from the pituitary. This is a hallmark of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism , often associated with conditions like stress, low body fat, and excessive exercise , all of which are common in athletes, particularly those with low BMI. Why the other options are less likely: Primary ovarian failure (Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism) : This would be characterized by high FSH and LH , not low, which is inconsistent with this patient's lab results. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism : Again, this would imply high FSH and LH , not the low levels seen here. Normogonadotropic normogonadism : This would imply normal FSH and LH levels, which are not observed in this case.

questions.text: A couple presents with infertility even with 2 years of unprotected intercourse. The seminal analysis reveals volume of 2 ml, concentration of 4 million/ml, progressive motility of 55%, and morphology 45%. The wife's hormone levels were normal with bilateral spillage of dye from both fallopian tubes on HSG. What percentage of couples can be attributed to unexplained infertility?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

25% In the case of infertility , when both partners undergo testing and no obvious cause is identified, it is referred to as unexplained infertility . This means that standard diagnostic tests (such as semen analysis for the male and fallopian tube patency testing for the female) do not reveal any abnormalities that would explain the infertility. From the provided data: The male partner's semen analysis shows some potential issues: Volume: 2 ml (normal range: 1.5–5 ml) Sperm concentration: 4 million/ml (low; normal is >15 million/ml) Progressive motility: 55% (normal > 40%) Sperm morphology: 45% (normal > 4%) This suggests oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OAT) , which could be a factor in infertility. However, the woman has normal hormone levels and her HSG shows bilateral spillage of dye , indicating no issues with her fallopian tubes. In this context, the couple's infertility could be attributed to unexplained infertility after excluding male and female factor issues. Prevalence of Unexplained Infertility: Unexplained infertility accounts for approximately 25% of couples experiencing infertility. This means that even after thorough testing, no clear cause can be identified in these couples.

Highyeild:

Latest WHO Recommendations for Normal Semen Analysis Reference Values. Latest WHO standard for semen analysis - 2010: Volume: 1.5-5.0 mL pH: >7.2 Viscosity: <3 (scale 0-4) Sperm concentration: >15 million/mL Total sperm number: >39 million/ejaculate Per cent motility: >32% Forward progression: >2 (scale 0-4) Normal morphology: > 4% Round cells: <1 million/mL Sperm agglutination: <2 (scale 0-3)

Table:

#MANTRA Semen Analysis Terminology ● Normospermia ○ All semen parameters normal ● Oligozoospermia / oligospermia ○ Decreased sperm number < 20 million/ml ● Asthenozoospermia/asthenospermia ○ Decreased sperm motility ● Teratozoospermia ○ Increased abnormal forms of sperm ● Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia ○ All sperm variables abnormal ● Azoospermia ○ No sperm in semen ● Aspermia ○ No ejaculate (ejaculation failure) ● Leucocytospermia ○ Increased white cells in semen ● Necrozoospermia ○ All sperms non - viable or non-motile

questions.text: Which of the ovarian structure is responsible for the following finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Corpus luteum The corpus luteum is the structure in the ovary responsible for the hormonal changes after ovulation, particularly the production of progesterone . It forms from the remnants of the graffian follicle after the egg is released during ovulation. The primary role of the corpus luteum is to secrete progesterone, which helps in the maintenance of the uterine lining for a potential pregnancy. If pregnancy does not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates, leading to a decrease in progesterone levels and the onset of menstruation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Secondary follicle : An early stage of follicular development, characterized by the presence of granulosa cells, theca interna, and an antrum, but it has not yet ovulated or formed a corpus luteum. Option: B. Theca interna : These are cells in the ovarian follicle that help in the production of androgens, which are converted into estrogens by the granulosa cells. Option: C. Granulosa cells : These cells surround the oocyte within the follicle and are involved in estrogen production and follicular maturation, but they do not form the corpus luteum.

questions.text: Dr. Priya is conducting a talk on the screening of cervical cancer with Pap smear. She works in a clinic in a low resource setting and she was planning to screen a woman in her 20s. Which of the following is true regarding cervical cancer screening guidelines in her workplace?

options.label: A
options.text: Co-testing (pap and Hr HPV) every 5 years starting at 25 years

options.label: B
options.text: Pap smear every 3 years, starting at 21 yrs

options.label: C
options.text: Hr HPV testing every 5 years starting at 30 yrs

options.label: D
options.text: Pap smear every 5 years starting at 21 years

questions.correct_answer: B. Pap smear every 3 years, starting at 21 yrs
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pap smear every 3 years, starting at 21 yrs In low-resource settings, cervical cancer screening is often done through Pap smear testing, and the guidelines for screening are based on age, the availability of resources, and the prevalence of human papillomavirus (HPV) infections. According to the current guidelines for cervical cancer screening: Pap smear testing should start at age 21 years, regardless of sexual activity, and should be repeated every 3 years until the age of 29. For women aged 30 and above , HPV testing can be added to Pap smear testing (co-testing), or HPV testing alone can be done, typically every 5 years . In this case, since Dr. Priya is planning to screen a woman in her 20s , the most appropriate guideline would be to start Pap smear screening at age 21 , with repeat testing every 3 years.

Highyeild:

Pap Smear Next step Normal/Reactive ● Resume Pap smear as per ACOG Inflammation/Infection ● Treatment of Infection ● Repeat Pap smear after 4 to 6 months ASCUS Options are: ● Repeat Pap Smear after 6 months ○ If Pap smear report is ASCUS after 6 months also, then do colposcopy ● If the female is > 30 years ,do HPV -DNA testing . If HPV DNA test is positive then do colposcopy ● Immediate colposcopy LSIL ● Colposcopy -Gold standard + endocervical curettage If lesion is visible-punch biopsy HSIL ● Colposcopy-Gold standard and endocervical curettage -which is mandatory ● If lesion is visible-punch biopsy
